reviewText: We love the Boy! what a girl / Boarding House these good and clear movie, thank for great black and white Movie.

This was a chance to see one of my favorite funny guys before he was a hit on early tv. Tim Moore headlines this musical revue on film with some neat footage of the Nat Cole Trio. I didn't know much about Moore until Jack Parr had him his show one night. He told more stories about the chitlin' circuit that had Parr on the floor and the audience in hysterics. Great all-black cast film history.
this item is the wrost item that i ever have gotten so save you're money this item is no good

"Race movies," a genre unique to the United States between 1915 and 1948, were quite popular with black Southern audiences and in Northern industrial cities that had large African-American communities. After the successful legal desegregation of the film industry in '48, this type of movie vanished, literally. Today, only a fifth of the original 500 race films still exist. SYNOPSES-- BOARDING HOUSE BLUES-- Performers who reside at Moms Mabley's theatrical boarding house put on a stage show to save their Harlem digs from foreclosure. The story's an excuse to hang a marvelous vaudeville-like variety program on. (Watch for the one-legged dancer 'Crip' Heard!) BOY! WHAT A GIRL!-- Two struggling variety show producers try to convince a wealthy Chicagoan to bankroll half their costs. Features Tim Moore, TV's "Kingfish" of THE AMOS 'N' ANDY SHOW as an ex-boxer disguised as a rich dame who's supposedly putting up the rest of the cash. KILLER DILLER-- As with "Boardinghouse," this thinly-plotted movie is in reality an all-black variety show featuring some legendary talents. There's swing music, singers, tappers (Clark Bros.), comics (Moms Mabley, et al), cool sounds (King Cole Trio) and lots more in this delightful document of mid-20th Century African-American entertainment. Related item: MILL CREEK's JAZZ 10 MOVIE PACK features nine films not found here. Musicians include Cab Calloway, Duke Ellington, the King Cole Trio, Louis Jordan and more! Parenthetical numbers preceding titles are 1 to 10 viewer poll ratings found at a film resource website. (6.6) Boarding House Blues (1948) - Mos Mabley/Dusty Fletcher/Marcellus Wilson/Marie Cook/Gus Smith/Lucky Millender/Una Mae Carlisle/Bull Moose Jackson/Berry Bros./Lewis & White/'Crip' Heard (6.0) Boy! What a Girl! (1947) - Tim Moore/Elwood Smith/Duke Williams/Alan Jackson/Brown Dots/Slam Stewart Trio/International Jitterbuggers/Gene Krupa (6.0) Killer Diller (1948) - Dusty Fletcher/George Wiltshire/Butterfly McQueen/Nellie Hill/Gus Smith/Moms Mabley/King Cole Trio/Clark Bros./Four Congaroos
